I'm not a bad person. I'm not a bad person.
So you've known Mr. Goh since his audition, and you came to see his debut live performance.
Yes, I went to Ikebukuro. How was it? I went to Ikebukuro. How was it?
I left with one word... "It was done right." It was done right.
I've been watching your videos on the latest riffraff, and you've been watching them.
The recent TV series "Calling the Great Persons" is very interesting.

Let's think about live goods.
Well, of course, Rough Rough has a variety of goods, so let's take a look at them first.
Here are some towels, tote baggers, T-shirts, and acrylic stands.
So, in short, plain goods, since it's still early in our history.
I think it's a good idea to have some basic goods like this, since we're trying so hard to make it more interesting.
You're right. Do you have any favorites? This one right now... Yes, Fujisaki.
The acrylic stand is so cute!
How about one by one? Just one by one... Is it okay to collect them all together?
When did this start? Acrylic stands didn't exist in the past.
The acrylic stand is a very popular item.
It's also spread by taking them along on a trip.
So goods have changed a lot between then and now? It's totally different. What was the mainstream in the past?
I'm a collector of celebrity goods, so I've been selling them since the Showa period.
Back then, phone cards and cell phone straps were the mainstream.
A strap... a real strap. Do you know "Galaga Kei"? I know. There were straps for Galapagos.
But towels and stuff like that haven't changed? Towels are still the same, but now they've become muffler towels.
It used to be a regular festival towel after festivals, but it became popular to put it around your neck at festivals, and it became a part of idol culture.
And then it was replaced by pressed towels? And the pressed towel at the same time?
Is that right? Have you seen any unusual goods so far?
For example, this is an Ebichu merchandise.
It doesn't look like idol goods.
This is nice!
The T-shirt is from Seishun Coco.
The T-shirt is from Seishun Coco.

Yes, it is
It's really nice!

It's really good.

It's expensive, but it's so well made that it didn't sell because it was too expensive.
I see.

This is a bit of a problem. It's important to be fashionable in moderation.
Don't be too fashionable.
I think that T-shirt is a little too fashionable.
It's true that this picture is very cool.
I've seen idol geeks in Hello Project.
Hello Project used to mainly produce embarrassing goods.

That was not well received by the otaku.
It was bad, wasn't it?
In short, they wanted to carry the members' names and so on.
I see... so it's really tiny.
It's like, "Well, you can use it for everyday use if it only has the tour title in small letters," or something.
But that's not it.
I want to carry my favorite group or individual.
I see.

But that's not enough to satisfy the idol otaku in me.
I see.
I see... so you want to say you're pushing for it.
Yes, I have a plan to sell a few acrylic stands.

I'm going to recreate the scene from the song "Ten Billion Points" with the choreography of that moment for each member.
